column6: Presentational markupMany markup languages have purposely avoided presentational markups. For markup languages based on SGML and XML, CSS is used as a presentation layer.

column2: Interactive technical documents, infographics, blogsUses and Examples of the Computable Document Format (CDF), Wolfram.com.

column6: yesIncludes basic presentational content and SVG and MathML markup, officially supported in version 1.3. In select XML editors and management systems, the images and content can be viewed as rendered, through CSS mostly.
yesPresentational content is supported through SVG and MathML markup. In select XML editors, the images can be viewed as rendered.
yesPresentational markup is deprecated as of XHTML 1.0 and no longer allowed as of XHTML 1.1
yesPresentational markup is deprecated as of HTML 4.0

column2: Formatted Technical documents, Hypertext documents, E-mail

column6: yesMathML comes in two mark-up syntaxes: a semantic and a presentational.

column5: yesuses Content MathML, OpenMath or other formats for formulae
column6: yesExact presentation of symbols can be specified in OMDoc, these specifications are used when transforming OMDoc to a presentational format.

column2: Multi-purpose (notes, project management, publishing, literate programming)

Academic documentsMulti-purposeWhile Donald Knuth wrote TeX for Academic publications and Leslie Lamport wrote LaTeX for similar purpose, packages are available from Comprehensive TeX Archive Network (CTAN) for nonacademic purposes, e.g., writing scripts.
